standard_metadata.standard_description: Make a line plot to display a data set of measurements in fractions of a unit (1/2, 1/4, 1/8). Solve problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions by using information presented in line plots.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Interpret line plots with fraction addition and subtraction

question.content: For $7$ days, Tom recorded the number of hours he slept each night.  He rounded each time to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of an hour and plotted it on the line plot below. Each point represents one night.    **How many more hours did Tom sleep on the night he slept the most than the night he slept the least?**     hours

images.alt: A line plot labeled Sleep, in hours, from 7 to 9 with tick marks at every one-fourth unit. Above the tick mark at seven and one-fourth is a column of two dots. Above the tick mark at seven and three-fourths is a column of three blue dots. Above the the tick mark at eight and one-fourth is 1 dot. Above the tick mark at eight and two-fourths there is one blue dot.

hints.content: Tom slept the *most* on the night he slept $8\dfrac{2}{4}$ hours.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A line plot labeled sleep, in hours, from 7 to 9 with tick marks every one-fourth unit. Above the tick mark at seven and one-fourth is a column of two light blue dots. Above the tick mark at seven and three-fourths is a column of three light blue dots. Above the tick marks at eight and one-fourth is a light blue dot. Above the tick mark at eight and two-fourths there is one dark blue dot.

hints.content: Tom slept the *least* on one of the nights he slept $7\dfrac{1}{4}$ hours.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A line plot labeled sleep, in hours, from 7 to 9 with tick marks every one-fourth unit.  Above the tick mark at seven and one-fourth is a column of two dark blue dots. Above the tick mark at seven and three-fourths is a column of three light blue dots. Above the tick marks at eight and one-fourth is one light blue dot. Above the tick mark at eight and two-fourths there is one light blue dot.

hints.content: To determine the difference between the night he slept the most and the night he slept the least, we subtract the two values.    $8\dfrac{2}{4}\text{ hours} - 7\dfrac{1}{4}\text{ hours}$
$\begin{align} \text{most sleep} && 8\dfrac{2}{4}\\\\  - \text{least sleep} &&- 7\dfrac{1}{4}  \\ \hline\\ \text{difference} &&  1\dfrac{1}{4} \end{align}$
The difference between the night Tom slept the most and the night Tom slept the least is $1\dfrac{1}{4}$ hours.

question.content: Eve surveys the students in her classroom to find out how much time they spent doing their homework last night.  The results are plotted in the line plot below.  The measurements are rounded to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of an hour. Each point represents a student.    **What was the difference in time between the longest time and the shortest time?**  $\text{ hours}$

images.alt: A line plot labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks every one-fourth unit. Above the tick mark at two-fourths is one dot. Above the tick mark at three-fourths is a column of four dots. Above the tick mark at one is a column of two dots. Above the tick mark at one and one-fourth is a column of five dots. Above the tick mark at one and two-fourths is a column of four dots. Above the tick mark at one and three-fourths is one dot.

hints.content: The *longest* time spent doing homework was $1\dfrac34$ hours.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A line plot labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks every one-fourth unit. Above the tick mark at two-fourths is one light blue dot. Above the tick mark at three-fourths is a column of four light blue dots. Above the tick mark at one is a column of two light blue dots. Above the tick mark at one and one-fourth is a column of five light blue dots. Above the tick mark at one and two-fourths is a column of four light blue dots. Above the tick mark at one and three-fourths is one dark blue dot.

hints.content: The *shortest* time spent doing homework was $\dfrac{2}{4}$ of an hour.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A line plot labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks every one-fourth unit. Above the tick mark at two-fourths is one dark blue dot. Above the tick mark at three-fourths is a column of four light blue dots. Above the tick mark at one is a column of two light blue dots. Above the tick mark at one and one-fourth is a column of five light blue dots. Above the tick mark at one and two-fourths is a column of four light blue dots. Above the tick mark at one and three-fourths is one light blue dot.

hints.content: To determine the difference between the longest time and the shortest time, we want to subtract the two values.  $1\dfrac{3}{4}\text{ hours}-\dfrac{2}{4}\text{ hour}$
$\begin{align} \text{longest} && 1\frac{3}{4}\\ \\  - \underline{\text{shortest}} && \underline{- \frac{2}{4}}\\ \\ \text{difference} && 1\frac{1}{4}\\ \end{align}$
The difference between the longest time doing homework and the shortest time doing homework is $1\dfrac{1}{4}$ hours.

question.content: The owner of a produce stand is selling baskets of peaches, priced by the kilogram.  She rounded each measurements to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of a kilogram and plotted it on the line plot below. Each point represents one basket of peaches.     **How much heavier is the heaviest basket than the second heaviest basket?**     kilograms

images.alt: A line plot labeled 3 to 7 with tick marks at each one-half unit. Tick marks 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7 are labeled. Above tick mark 3 there is one dot. Above tick mark three and one-half there is a column of two dots. Above tick mark four and one-half, there is a column of three dots. Above tick mark 5 there is a column of two dots. Above tick mark six and one-half there is one dot.

hints.content: The *heaviest* basket of peaches weighs $6\dfrac12$ kilograms.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A line plot labeled 3 to 7 with tick marks at each one-half unit. Tick marks 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7 are labeled. Above tick mark 3 there is one light blue dot. Above tick mark three and one-half there is a column of two light blue dots. Above tick mark four and one-half, there is a column of three light blue dots. Above tick mark 5 there is a column of two light blue dots. Above tick mark six and one-half there is one dark blue dot.

hints.content: The *second heaviest* basket of peaches weighs $5$ kilograms.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A line plot labeled 3 to 7 with tick marks at each one-half unit. Tick marks 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7 are labeled. Above tick mark 3 there is one light blue dot. Above tick mark three and one-half there is a column of two light blue dots. Above tick mark four and one-half, there is a column of three light blue dots. Above tick mark 5 there is a column of two dark blue dots. Above tick mark six and one-half there is one light blue dot.

hints.content: To determine the difference between the heaviest basket and the second heaviest basket, we subtract the two values.    $6\dfrac12\text{ kg} - 5\text{ kg}$
$\begin{align} \text{heaviest} && 6\frac12\\ \\  - \underline{\text{second heaviest}} && \underline{- 5\quad}  \\ \\ \text{difference} && 1 \frac12\\ \end{align}$
The difference between the heaviest basket and the second heaviest basket is $1\dfrac12$ kilograms.

question.content: Students in Ms. Valendra’s science class planted $13$ conifers around the school yard. After one month, they measured the heights of the conifers.  They rounded each measurement to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of an inch and plotted the results on the line plot below. Each point represents one conifer.    **How much taller is the tallest conifer than the shortest conifer?**     inches

images.alt: A line plot labeled 6 to 10 with tick marks every one-fourth unit. Above the tick mark for six and one-fourth is a column of three dots. Above the tick mark for six and three-fourths is a column of two dots. Above the tick mark for seven and two-fourths there is one dot. Above the tick mark at eight and one-fourth is a column of four dots. Above the tick mark for eight and three-fourths is a column of two dots. Above the tick mark for nine and two-fourths is one dot.

hints.content: The *tallest* conifer measured $9\dfrac{2}{4}$ inches.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A line plot labeled 6 to 10 with tick marks every one-fourth unit. Above the tick mark for six and one-fourth is a column of three light blue dots. Above the tick mark for six and three-fourths is a column of two light blue dots. Above the tick mark for seven and two-fourths there is one light blue dot. Above the tick mark at eight and one-fourth is a column of four light blue dots. Above the tick mark for eight and three-fourths is a column of two light blue dots. Above the tick mark for nine and two-fourths is one dark blue dot.

hints.content: The *shortest* conifer measured $6\dfrac14$ inches.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A line plot labeled 6 to 10 with tick marks every one-fourth unit. Above the tick mark for six and one-fourth is a column of three dark blue dots. Above the tick mark for six and three-fourths is a column of two light blue dots. Above the tick mark for seven and two-fourths there is one light blue dot. Above the tick mark at eight and one-fourth is a column of four light blue dots. Above the tick mark for eight and three-fourths is a column of two light blue dots. Above the tick mark for nine and two-fourths is one light blue dot.

hints.content: To determine the difference between the tallest and the shortest conifer, we subtract the two values.    $9\dfrac{2}{4}\text{ in} - 6\dfrac{1}{4}\text{ in}$
$\begin{align} \text{tallest} && 9\dfrac{2}{4}\\\\  - \underline{\text{shortest}} && \underline{- 6\dfrac{1}{4}}  \\\\ \text{difference} &&  3\dfrac14 \end{align}$
The difference between the height of the tallest tree and the height of the shortest tree is $3\dfrac14$ inches.

question.content: The weights of $11$ different babies are recorded on the line plot below.  Each weight was rounded to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{8}$ pound. Each point represents a baby.     **What is the difference, in weight, between the two heaviest babies?**    pounds

images.alt: A line plot labeled 6 and four eighths to nine and four eighths with tick marks every one-eighth unit. Above the tick mark at six and six-eighths is one dot. Above the tick mark at seven and one-eighth is a column of three dots. Above the tick mark at seven and two-eighths is a column of two dots. Above the tick mark at eight and three-eighths there is a column of three dots. Above the tick mark at eight and four-eighths there is one dot. Above the tick mark at nine and two-eighths is one dot.

hints.content: The *heaviest* baby weighs $9\dfrac{2}{8}$ pounds.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A line plot labeled 6 and four eighths to nine and four eighths with tick marks every one-eighth unit. Above the tick mark at six and six-eighths is one light blue dot. Above the tick mark at seven and one-eighth is a column of three light blue dots. Above the tick mark at seven and two-eighths is a column of two light blue dots. Above the tick mark at eight and three-eighths there is a column of three light blue dots. Above the tick mark at eight and four-eighths there is one light blue dot. Above the tick mark at nine and two-eighths is one dark blue dot.

hints.content: The *second heaviest* baby weighs $8\dfrac{4}{8}$ pounds.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A line plot labeled 6 and four eighths to nine and four eighths with tick marks every one-eighth unit. Above the tick mark at six and six-eighths is one light blue dot. Above the tick mark at seven and one-eighth is a column of three light blue dots. Above the tick mark at seven and two-eighths is a column of two light blue dots. Above the tick mark at eight and three-eighths there is a column of three light blue dots. Above the tick mark at eight and four-eighths there is one dark blue dot. Above the tick mark at nine and two-eighths is one light blue dot.

hints.content: To determine the difference in weight between the two heaviest babies, we want to subtract.      ${9\dfrac{2}{8}}\text{ pounds} - {8\dfrac{4}{8}}\text{ pounds}$

$\begin{align} \text{heaviest} && {9\dfrac{2}{8}}\\ \\  - \underline{\text{second heaviest}} && \underline{- {8\dfrac{4}{8}}} \end{align}$  We cannot subtract ${\dfrac{2}{8}} - \dfrac{4}{8}$, because ${\dfrac{2}{8}}$ is **less** than $\dfrac{4}{8}$.

We can regroup ${9\dfrac{2}{8}}$ so that the fractional part is **greater** than ${\dfrac{4}{8}}$.  $\begin{align} 9\dfrac{2}{8} &= 9+  \dfrac{2}{8} \\\\ &= {8 +  1 +  \dfrac{2}{8}}\\\\ &= {8+  \dfrac{8}{8} +  \dfrac{2}{8}} \\\\ &= {8 \dfrac{10}{8}}  \end{align}$
Now, we can subtract.  $8\dfrac{10}{8} - 8\dfrac{4}{8}   = \dfrac{6}{8}$
The difference, in weight, between the two heaviest babies is $\dfrac{6}{8}$ of a pound.

question.content: The owner of a produce stand is selling bunches of grapes, priced by the pound.  She rounded each measurement to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{8}$ of a pound and plotted them on the line plot below. Each point represents one bunch of grapes.     **How much heavier is the heaviest bunch than the lightest bunch?**     pounds

images.alt: A line plot labeled 0 to 2  with tick marks every one-eighth unit. Above the tick mark at five-eighths is one dot. Above the tick mark for six-eighths is a column of two dots. Above the tick mark at 1 there is a column of three dots. Above the tick mark at one and four-eighths is a column of two dots. Above the tick mark for one and five-eighths is a column of four dots. Above the tick mark for one and seven-eighths is one dot.

hints.content: The *heaviest* bunch of grapes weighs $1\dfrac78$ pounds.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A line plot labeled 0 to 2  with tick marks every one-eighth unit. Above the tick mark at five-eighths is one light blue dot. Above the tick mark for six-eighths is a column of two light blue dots. Above the tick mark at 1 there is a column of three light blue dots. Above the tick mark at one and four-eighths is a column of two light blue dots. Above the tick mark for one and five-eighths is a column of four light blue dots. Above the tick mark for one and seven-eighths is one dark blue dot.

hints.content: The *lightest* bunch of grapes weighs $\dfrac58$ of a pound.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A line plot labeled 0 to 2  with tick marks every one-eighth unit. Above the tick mark at five-eighths is one dark blue dot. Above the tick mark for six-eighths is a column of two light blue dots. Above the tick mark at 1 there is a column of three light blue dots. Above the tick mark at one and four-eighths is a column of two light blue dots. Above the tick mark for one and five-eighths is a column of four light blue dots. Above the tick mark for one and seven-eighths is one light blue dot.

hints.content: To determine the difference between the heaviest bunch and the lightest bunch, we subtract the two values.   $1\dfrac{7}{8}\text{ lb} - \dfrac{5}{8}\text{ lb}$
$\begin{align} \text{heaviest} && 1\dfrac{7}{8}\\ \\  - \underline{\text{least heavy}} && \underline{- \dfrac{5}{8}}  \\ \\ \text{difference} &&  1\dfrac{2}{8} \end{align}$
The difference between the heaviest bunch and the lightest bunch is $1\dfrac{2}{8}$ or $1\dfrac{1}{4}$ pounds.

question.content: Pietro is measuring the thickness of his favorite books. He  rounds his measurements to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{8}$ inch and records the information on the line plot below. Each point represents one book.    **What is the total thickness of the two thickest books?**     inches

images.alt: A line plot labeled Thickness, in inches, from 0 to 2  with tick marks every one-eighth unit. Dots are plotted as follows: 3 dots above one and one-eighth, 1 dot above one and two-eighths, 4 dots above one and five-eighths, 2 dots above one and six-eighths, and 1 dot above the 2.

hints.content: The thickest book measured $2$ inches.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A line plot labeled 0 to 2  with tick marks every one-eighth unit. Faded dots are plotted as follows: 3 dots above one and one-eighth, 1 dot above one and two-eighths, 4 dots above one and five-eighths, and 2 dots above one and six-eighths. A dark dot is plotted above the 2.

hints.content: The second thickest book measured $1\dfrac{6}{8}$ inches.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A line plot labeled 0 to 2  with tick marks every one-eighth unit. Faded dots are plotted as follows: 3 dots above one and one-eighth, 1 dot above one and two-eighths, 4 dots above one and five-eighths, and 1 dot above the 2. Two dark dots are above one and six-eighths.

hints.content: To determine the total thickness of the two thickest books, we need to add.  $1\dfrac{6}{8}+2$
Let's add the whole numbers and then the fractions.  $\begin{align} \text{Thickness}&={(1+2)}+\dfrac{6}{8}\\ &\\ &= 3+\frac{6}{8}\\ \\ &=3\dfrac{6}{8} \end{align}$
The total thickness of the two thickest books is $3\dfrac{6}{8}$ or $3\dfrac{3}{4} \text { inches}$.

question.content: During science class, groups of students measure out different volumes of vinegar.  The line plot below shows the amount of vinegar used by $12$ groups, rounded to the nearest $\dfrac12 \text{ mL}$. Each point represents one group.      **What is the total amount of vinegar, in milliliters, used by the $3$ groups that used the most?**    $\text{ mL}$

images.alt: A line plot labeled 4 to 8 with tick marks every one-half unit labeled with a tick mark and number. Above tick mark four and one-half there is a  column of two dots. Above tick mark 5 there is a column of three dots. Above tick mark six and one-half there is a column of two dots. Above tick mark 7, there is a column of two dots. Above tick mark seven and one-half, there is a column of three dots.

hints.content: The $3$ groups that used the greatest amount of vinegar each used $7\dfrac12 \text{ mL}$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A line plot labeled 4 to 8 with tick marks every one-half unit labeled with a tick mark and number. Above tick mark four and one-half there is a  column of two light blue dots. Above tick mark 5 there is a column of three light blue dots. Above tick mark six and one-half there is a column of two light blue dots. Above tick mark 7, there is a column of two light blue dots. Above tick mark seven and one-half, there is a column of three dark blue dots.

hints.content: To determine the total amount of vinegar used, we need to add.   $\text{Total}={7\dfrac12}+{7\dfrac12}+{7\dfrac12}$

Let's add the whole numbers then the fractions.  $\begin{align} \text{Total}&=(7+7+7)+\left({\dfrac12}+{\dfrac12}+{\dfrac12}\right)\\\\ &= 21+\dfrac{3}{2}\\\\ &=21+1\dfrac{1}{2}\\\\ &=22\dfrac{1}{2} \end{align}$
The total amount of vinegar used by the $3$ groups that used the most is $22\dfrac12 \text{ mL}$.

question.content: Scientists in Florida are measuring the masses of sea turtles as they hatch.  They create a line graph and plot the masses of $14$ turtles, rounded to the nearest $\dfrac14$ of an ounce. Each point represents a turtle.    **What is the combined mass, in ounces, of the $3$ lightest turtles?**       ounces

images.alt: A line plot labeled from 12 to 14 with tick marks every one-fourth unit. Above the twelve and one-fourth tick mark is a column of three dots. Above the twelve and two-fourths tick mark is a column of four dots. Above the tick mark at 13 is one dot. Above the tick mark at thirteen and one-fourth there is one dot.  At the thirteen and two-fourths tick mark there is a column of three dots. At the thirteen and three-fourths tick mark there is a column of two dots.

hints.content: The $3$ lightest turtles each have a mass of $12\dfrac14 \text{ ounces}$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A line plot labeled from 12 to 14 with tick marks every one-fourth unit. Above the twelve and one-fourth tick mark is a column of three dark blue dots. Above the twelve and two-fourths tick mark is a column of four light blue dots. Above the tick mark at 13 is one light blue dot. Above the tick mark at thirteen and one-fourth there is one light blue dot.  At the thirteen and two-fourths tick mark there is a column of three light blue dots. At the thirteen and three-fourths tick mark there is a column of two light blue dots.

hints.content: To determine the combined mass of the three lightest turtles, we need to add.   $\text{Total}={12\dfrac14}+{12\dfrac14}+{12\dfrac14}$
Let's add the whole numbers then the fractions.  $\begin{align} \text{Total}&=({12}+{12}+{12})+\left({\dfrac14}+{\dfrac14}+{\dfrac14}\right)\\\\ &= 36+\dfrac{3}{4}\\\\ &=36\dfrac{3}{4} \end{align}$
The combined mass of the $3$ lightest turtles is $36\dfrac34 \text{ ounces}$.

question.content: Gino recorded how much milk his family drank each week in February. He graphed the volumes, to the nearest $\dfrac14$ of a gallon, on the line plot below. Each point represents one week.    **What is the total volume of milk Gino's family drank on the $2$ weeks where they drank the most milk?**     gallons

images.alt: A line plot labeled 1 to 4 with tick marks at every one-fourth unit. Above tick mark one and two-fourths there is a column of two dots. Above tick mark two and one-fourth there is one dot. Above tick mark three and three-fourths there is one dot.

hints.content: The week Gino's family drank the most milk, they drank $3\dfrac34$ gallon.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A line plot labeled 1 to 4 with tick marks at every one-fourth unit. Above tick mark one and two-fourths there is a column of two light blue dots. Above tick mark two and one-fourth there is one light blue dot. Above tick mark three and three-fourths there is one dark blue dot.

hints.content: The week Gino's family drank the second largest amount of milk, they drank $2\dfrac14$ gallon.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A line plot labeled 1 to 4 with tick marks at every one-fourth unit. Above tick mark one and two-fourths there is a column of two light blue dots. Above tick mark two and one-fourth there is one dark blue dot. Above tick mark three and three-fourths there is one light blue dot.

hints.content: To find how much milk the family drank in two weeks with the largest volume of milk, we add the values.    $3\dfrac{3}{4}\text{ gal} + 2\dfrac14\text{ gal}$

Let's add the whole numbers then the fractions.  $\begin{align} 3\dfrac34+2\dfrac14&=(3+2)+\left(\dfrac{3}{4}+\dfrac{1}{4} \right)\\\\ \phantom{9\dfrac12+8\dfrac34} &= 5+\dfrac{4}{4}\\\\ \phantom{9\dfrac12+8\dfrac34} &=5+1\\\\ \phantom{9\dfrac12+8\dfrac34} &=6 \end{align}$
Gino's family drank $6$ gallons of milk in the $2$ weeks where they drank the most milk

question.content: Amy ran $8$ miles.  She recorded how long it took her to run each mile, rounded to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of a minute. Each point represents one mile.    **How long did it take Amy to run her fastest and slowest mile combined?**     minutes

images.alt: A line plot labeled 8 to 10 with tick marks every one-fourth unit . Above tick mark eight and three-fourths, there is a column of two dots. Above tick mark 9, there is a column of three dots. Above tick mark nine and one-fourth, there is a column of two dots. Above tick mark nine and two-fourths, there is one dot.

hints.content: Amy's ran her *fastest* mile in $8\dfrac34$ minutes.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A line plot labeled 8 to 10 with tick marks every one-fourth unit . Above tick mark eight and three-fourths, there is a column of two dark blue dots. Above tick mark 9, there is a column of three light blue dots. Above tick mark nine and one-fourth, there is a column of two light blue dots. Above tick mark nine and two-fourths, there is one light blue dot.

hints.content: Amy's ran her *slowest* mile in $9\dfrac{2}{4}$ minutes.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A line plot labeled 8 to 10 with tick marks every one-fourth unit . Above tick mark eight and three-fourths, there is a column of two light blue dots. Above tick mark 9, there is a column of three light blue dots. Above tick mark nine and one-fourth, there is a column of two light blue dots. Above tick mark nine and two-fourths, there is one dark blue dot.

hints.content: To find how long it took Amy to run her slowest and fastest mile combined, we add the two values.     $9\dfrac{2}{4}\text{ min} + 8\dfrac{3}{4}\text{ min}$
$\begin{align} 9\dfrac24+8\dfrac34&=(8+9)+\left(\dfrac{2}{4}+\dfrac{3}{4} \right)\\\\ &= 17+\dfrac{5}{4}\\\\ &=17+1\dfrac{1}{4}\\\\ &=18\dfrac{1}{4} \end{align}$
It took Amy $18\dfrac14$ minutes to run her fastest and slowest mile combined.

question.content: Chelsea records the number of quarts of water she gives her garden over $4$ days. She rounds the measurements to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{8}$ quart and then records the information on the line plot below. Each point represents one day.    **What is the total number of quarts of water Chelsea used over these $4$ days?**     quarts

images.alt: A line plot labeled Water, in quarts, from 7 to 10 with tick marks every one-eighth unit. Above the tick mark above seven and four-eighths, there is a column of two dots.  Above the tick mark for eight and six-eighths, there is one dot. Above the tick mark for nine and two-eighths, there is one dot.

hints.content: To determine the total number of quarts of water Chelsea used, we want to add all of the values.   $\text{Total}=7\dfrac{4}{8}+7\dfrac{4}{8}+8\dfrac{6}{8}+9\dfrac{2}{8}$

Let's add the whole numbers then add the fractions.  $\begin{align} \text{Total}&=(7+7+8+9)+\left(\dfrac{4}{8}+\dfrac{4}{8} +\dfrac{6}{8}+\dfrac{2}{8}\right)\\\\ &= 31+\dfrac{16}{8}\\\\ &=31+2\\\\ &=33 \end{align}$
Chelsea used $33$ quarts of water on her garden.

question.content: Ms. White measured the number of ounces of juice left behind by $3$ students after breakfast.  She  plotted the data on the line plot shown below. Each point represents a student.     **What is the total amount of juice that was left behind by the $3$ students?**     ounces

images.alt: A line plot labeled 1 to 4 with tick marks at every one-fourth unit. Above the tick mark for two and one-fourth, there is a column of two dots. Above the tick mark at three and one-fourth, there is one dot.

hints.content: To determine the total amount of juice left behind, we want to add all of the values.    $\text{Total}=2\dfrac{1}{4}+2\dfrac{1}{4}+3\dfrac{1}{4}$

Let's add the whole numbers and then add fractions.  $\begin{align} \text{Total}&=({2+2+3)}+{\left(\dfrac{1}{4} +\dfrac{1}{4}+\dfrac{1}{4}\right)}\\\\ &= 7+\dfrac{3}{4}\\\\ &=7\dfrac{3}{4} \end{align}$
The total amount of juice left behind by the $3$ students is $7\dfrac{3}{4}\text{ ounces}$.

question.content: Ted analyzes how much sugar is in $3$ popular candy bars.  He records the data on the line plot below. Each point represents one candy bar.    **How many total grams of sugar are in all $3$ candy bars combined?**     grams

images.alt: A line plot labeled 20 to 30 with tick marks every one-half unit. Above the tick mark for 21 and one-half, there is one dot. Above the tick mark for thirty, there is a column of two dots.

hints.content: To determine the total amount of sugar we need to add.  $\text{Total}=21\dfrac{1}{2}+30+30$
Let's add the whole numbers and then add the fractions.  $\begin{align} \text{Total}&={(21+30+30)}+{\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)}\\\\ &= 81+\dfrac{1}{2} \end{align}$
The total amount of sugar in all $3$ candy bars is $81\dfrac{1}{2} \text{ grams}$.

question.content: In a science class experiment, the weights of $4$ baking soda samples were measured and recorded on the line plot below. Each point represents one sample.    **What is the total number of grams of baking soda in all $4$ samples?**      grams

images.alt: A line plot labeled 2 to 5 with tick marks every one-half unit. Above the tick mark at two and one-half is one dot. Above  the tick mark at three and one-half is one dot. Above the tick mark at five there is a column of two dots.

hints.content: To determine the total number of grams we need to add.  $\text{Total}=2\dfrac{1}{2}+3\dfrac{1}{2} + 5+5$
Let's add the whole numbers then add the fractions.  $\begin{align} \text{Total}&=(2+3+5+5)+\left(\dfrac{1}{2}+\dfrac{1}{2}\right)\\\\ &= 15+\dfrac{2}{2}\\\\ &= 15+1\\\\ &=16 \end{align}$
The total amount of baking soda in the science experiment is $16$ grams.

question.content: The amount of rain that fell in Tokyo, Japan for $3$ consecutive days is shown on the line plot below.  The measurements are rounded to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of a centimeter. Each point represents one day.    **What was the total rainfall during these $3$ days?**     centimeters

images.alt: A line plot labeled 2 to 4 with tick marks every one-half unit. Above the tick mark at two and one-half is one dot. Above the tick mark at three and one-half is a column of two dots.

hints.content: To determine the total rainfall we need to add.  $\text{Total}=2\dfrac12+3\dfrac12+3\dfrac12$

Let's add the whole numbers then add the fractions.  $\begin{align}\text{Total}&=(2+3+3)+\left(\dfrac12+\frac12+\dfrac12\right)\\\\ &= 8+\dfrac{3}{2}\\\\ &= 8+1\dfrac{1}{2}\\\\ &= 9\dfrac{1}{2} \end{align}$
The total amount of rainfall in Tokyo during these $3$ days was $9\dfrac{1}{2}$ centimeters.
